title: Patient Global Impression of Improvement (PGI-I): A Comprehensive Implementation Guide
text: Patient Global Impression Improvement (PGI-) scale validated patient-reported outcome measure provides simple, direct assessment patients’ perceptions treatment efficacy. healthcare delivery increasingly prioritizes patient-centered care, PGI-emerged essential tool urogynecology medical specialties several reasons: Patient-Centered: Directly measures patient’s subjective experience improvement Simplicity: Single item reduces respondent burden Validity: Strong correlation condition-specific quality life measures Versatility: Applicable across diverse treatment modalities conditions Responsiveness: Sensitive clinically meaningful changes Patient Global Impression Improvement (PGI-) scale presented visual spectrum much better much worse.

title: Patient Global Impression of Improvement (PGI-I): A Comprehensive Implementation Guide
text: PGI-scale evolved Clinical Global Impression (CGI) scales originally developed psychiatric research. 2003, Yalcin Bump validated PGI-specifically women urinary incontinence, demonstrating : Strong correlation condition-specific quality life measures Excellent test-retest reliability (kappa = 0.75) High sensitivity treatment effects Strong association objective measures incontinence Since initial validation, PGI-incorporated numerous clinical trials practice guidelines urogynecology. adoption exemplifies shift toward patient-centered outcomes research clinical practice.

title: Patient Global Impression of Improvement (PGI-I): A Comprehensive Implementation Guide
text: Key Psychometric Properties PGI-Scale minimal important difference (MID) PGI-established studies score ≤2 (“much better” “much better”), indicating clinically significant improvement. threshold commonly used define “responders” clinical trials shown correspond meaningful improvements quality life measures.

title: Patient Global Impression of Improvement (PGI-I): A Comprehensive Implementation Guide
text: urogynScorer package provides standardized, robust method scoring analyzing PGI-data score_pgii() function. section demonstrates practical implementation PGI-scoring research clinical settings.

title: Patient Global Impression of Improvement (PGI-I): A Comprehensive Implementation Guide
text: score_pgii() function processes raw PGI-responses outputs original scores derived binary improvement indicator: Parameters score_pgii() function function returns tibble : * patient identifier column * pgii_score: original PGI-response (1-7 NA) * pgii_improved: Binary indicator (1 = improved [scores 1-3], 0 = improved [scores 4-7]) * pgii_n_valid: (Optional) Count valid responses

title: Patient Global Impression of Improvement (PGI-I): A Comprehensive Implementation Guide
text: Let’s start simple example using simulated patient data:
code: # Create sample dataset set.seed(123) # For reproducibility patient_data <- data.frame(   patient_id = paste0("P", 101:120),   treatment_group = rep(c("Surgery", "Conservative"), each = 10),   baseline_score = sample(5:25, 20, replace = TRUE),   pgii_response = c(sample(1:3, 10, replace = TRUE), sample(2:7, 10, replace = TRUE)) )  # Display sample of the data head(patient_data) %>%   kable() %>%   kable_styling(bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover", "condensed"),                  full_width = FALSE, position = "center") # Score PGI-I responses pgii_results <- score_pgii(   patient_data = patient_data,   item_name = "pgii_response",   id_column = "patient_id",   keep_n_valid = TRUE,   verbose = TRUE ) #> INFO [2025-03-29 03:51:50] Starting PGI-I score calculation #> INFO [2025-03-29 03:51:50] Input parameters: item_name = %s, id_column = %s, keep_n_valid = %s, verbose = %s, output_file = %spgii_responsepatient_idTRUETRUENULL #> INFO [2025-03-29 03:51:50] Input validation successful #> INFO [2025-03-29 03:51:50] Extracted data for %d patients20 #> INFO [2025-03-29 03:51:50] PGI-I scores calculated: %d valid, %d missing200  # Examine results head(pgii_results) %>%   kable() %>%   kable_styling(bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover", "condensed"),                  full_width = FALSE, position = "center")

title: Patient Global Impression of Improvement (PGI-I): A Comprehensive Implementation Guide
text: score_pgii() function appropriately handles missing data, returning NA original score binary improvement indicator responses missing: Rows missing PGI-responses
code: # Create dataset with missing values patient_data_missing <- patient_data # Set some responses to NA patient_data_missing$pgii_response[c(3, 7, 15)] <- NA  # Score data with missing values pgii_results_missing <- score_pgii(   patient_data = patient_data_missing,   item_name = "pgii_response",   id_column = "patient_id" )  # Examine specifically the rows with missing data pgii_results_missing %>%   filter(is.na(pgii_score)) %>%   kable(caption = "Rows with missing PGI-I responses") %>%   kable_styling(bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover", "condensed"),                  full_width = FALSE, position = "center")

title: Patient Global Impression of Improvement (PGI-I): A Comprehensive Implementation Guide
text: common application comparing treatment outcomes different intervention groups: Improvement Status Treatment Group Percentage Improved Treatment Group
code: # Join PGI-I results with original data combined_data <- left_join(patient_data, pgii_results, by = "patient_id")  # Create contingency table of improvement by treatment group improvement_table <- table(combined_data$treatment_group,                             factor(combined_data$pgii_improved,                                    levels = c(0, 1),                                    labels = c("Not Improved", "Improved")))  # Display the table improvement_table %>%   kable(caption = "Improvement Status by Treatment Group") %>%   kable_styling(bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover", "condensed"),                  full_width = FALSE, position = "center") # Calculate percentages within each group prop_table <- prop.table(improvement_table, 1) * 100 prop_table %>%   round(1) %>%   kable(caption = "Percentage Improved by Treatment Group") %>%   kable_styling(bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover", "condensed"),                  full_width = FALSE, position = "center")

previous_headings: 3. Analysis and Visualization of PGI-I Data > 3.2 Visual Representations
title: Patient Global Impression of Improvement (PGI-I): A Comprehensive Implementation Guide
text: Comprehensive visualization PGI-response profiles treatment group.
code: # Check if device is open before attempting to control it if (!is.null(dev.list())) {   dev.control(displaylist = "enable") }  # Calculate response proportions by treatment group response_profile <- combined_data %>%   group_by(treatment_group, pgii_score) %>%   summarize(count = n(), .groups = "drop") %>%   group_by(treatment_group) %>%   mutate(     proportion = count / sum(count) * 100,     cumulative = cumsum(proportion),     midpoint = cumulative - proportion/2,     improved = ifelse(pgii_score <= 3, "Improved", "Not Improved")   )  # Create response labels response_labels <- c(   "1" = "Very much better",   "2" = "Much better",   "3" = "A little better",   "4" = "No change",   "5" = "A little worse",   "6" = "Much worse",   "7" = "Very much worse" )  # Create a comprehensive visualization ggplot(response_profile, aes(x = treatment_group, y = proportion, fill = factor(pgii_score))) +   geom_bar(stat = "identity", position = "stack", width = 0.7) +   geom_text(aes(y = midpoint, label = paste0(round(proportion, 1), "%")),             color = "white", fontface = "bold", size = 3.5) +   scale_fill_viridis_d(     option = "D",     labels = response_labels,     guide = guide_legend(title = "PGI-I Response", reverse = FALSE)   ) +   geom_hline(yintercept = 50, linetype = "dashed", color = "white", size = 1) +   annotate("rect", xmin = 0.5, xmax = 2.5, ymin = 0, ymax = 50,             alpha = 0.2, fill = "white") +   labs(     title = "PGI-I Response Profile by Treatment Group",     subtitle = "Distribution of patient-reported improvement outcomes",     x = "Treatment Group",     y = "Proportion of Patients (%)"   ) +   theme(legend.position = "right") +   coord_flip()

what: 4. Integrating PGI-I with Other Outcome Measures
title: Patient Global Impression of Improvement (PGI-I): A Comprehensive Implementation Guide
text: PGI-valuable used part comprehensive assessment strategy. demonstrate integration hypothetical condition-specific measures: Correlation PGI-scores change condition-specific measures.
code: # Check if device is open before attempting to control it if (!is.null(dev.list())) {   dev.control(displaylist = "enable") }  # Simulate a condition-specific measure (e.g., symptom severity score) set.seed(456) combined_data$baseline_score <- sample(40:100, nrow(combined_data), replace = TRUE) combined_data$followup_score <- combined_data$baseline_score -                                 (15 + rnorm(nrow(combined_data), 0, 5)) * (4 - combined_data$pgii_score/2) combined_data$change_score <- combined_data$followup_score - combined_data$baseline_score combined_data$percent_change <- (combined_data$change_score / combined_data$baseline_score) * 100  # Create visualization showing relationship between PGI-I and change scores p1 <- ggplot(combined_data, aes(x = factor(pgii_score), y = change_score, fill = factor(pgii_score))) +   geom_boxplot(alpha = 0.7) +   scale_fill_viridis_d() +   labs(     title = "Relationship Between PGI-I and Absolute Change",     x = "PGI-I Score",     y = "Absolute Change in Symptom Score",     subtitle = "More negative values indicate greater improvement"   ) +   theme(legend.position = "none")  p2 <- ggplot(combined_data, aes(x = factor(pgii_score), y = percent_change, fill = factor(pgii_score))) +   geom_boxplot(alpha = 0.7) +   scale_fill_viridis_d() +   labs(     title = "Relationship Between PGI-I and Percent Change",     x = "PGI-I Score",     y = "Percent Change in Symptom Score (%)",     subtitle = "More negative values indicate greater improvement"   ) +   theme(legend.position = "none")  # Display side by side p1 + p2 + plot_layout(guides = "collect")

title: Patient Global Impression of Improvement (PGI-I): A Comprehensive Implementation Guide
text: PGI-provides direct assessment patient’s perception change. Clinical interpretation generally follows guidelines: Scores 1-2 (much/Much better): Strong treatment response, generally considered clinically significant improvement Score 3 (little better): Modest improvement, may may clinically meaningful Score 4 (change): Treatment produced perceptible improvement Scores 5-7 (Worsening): Treatment may ineffective potentially harmful Clinical Interpretation Recommended Actions

title: Patient Global Impression of Improvement (PGI-I): A Comprehensive Implementation Guide
text: research applications, PGI-offers several advantages: Simplicity: Easy administer straightforward interpret Patient-Centricity: Directly measures outcome relevant patients Complementarity: Works well alongside condition-specific measures Standardization: Facilitates comparison across different studies conditions Researchers typically use PGI-: * primary secondary outcome measure clinical trials * validation metric outcome instruments * threshold defining “responders” vs. “non-responders”

title: Patient Global Impression of Improvement (PGI-I): A Comprehensive Implementation Guide
text: valuable, PGI-several limitations consider: Single-item measure: Less reliable multi-item questionnaires Recall bias: Depends patient’s memory pre-treatment state Anchoring effects: Response may influenced recent experiences Ceiling/floor effects: May capture nuances extremes improvement/worsening Best practice use PGI-conjunction condition-specific measures , possible, objective clinical assessments.

title: Scoring the Pelvic Floor Distress Inventory (PFDI-20)
text: Pelvic Floor Distress Inventory (PFDI-20) validated questionnaire used urogynecology assess pelvic floor symptoms. vignette demonstrates compute subscale total scores using score_pfdi function.

title: Scoring the Pelvic Floor Distress Inventory (PFDI-20)
text: Ensure urogynScorer package installed:
code: # Install from GitHub (if not installed already) # devtools::install_github("mufflyt/urogynScorer")  # Load required packages library(urogynScorer) library(dplyr) library(readr)

title: Scoring the Pelvic Floor Distress Inventory (PFDI-20)
text: begin loading dataset contains responses PFDI-20 items:
code: # Load dataset data("pfdi_data")  # Check column names colnames(pfdi_data)

title: Scoring the Pelvic Floor Distress Inventory (PFDI-20)
text: PFDI-20 consists three subscales: - POPDI-6: Pelvic Organ Prolapse Distress Inventory (6 items) - CRADI-8: Colorectal-Anal Distress Inventory (8 items) - UDI-6: Urinary Distress Inventory (6 items) ensure flexibility, dynamically identify relevant columns:
code: # Select columns starting with "PFDI-" pfdi_cols <- grep("^PFDI-", colnames(pfdi_data), value = TRUE)  # Assign subscale columns popdi_cols <- grep("^PFDI-.*POPDI", pfdi_cols, value = TRUE)  # POPDI-6 cradi_cols <- grep("^PFDI-.*CRADI", pfdi_cols, value = TRUE)  # CRADI-8 udi_cols   <- grep("^PFDI-.*UDI", pfdi_cols, value = TRUE)    # UDI-6  # Verify correct assignment list(POPDI_6 = popdi_cols, CRADI_8 = cradi_cols, UDI_6 = udi_cols)

title: Scoring the Pelvic Floor Distress Inventory (PFDI-20)
text: Now, apply score_pfdi function compute subscale total scores:
code: # Score the PFDI-20 scored_pfdi <- score_pfdi(pfdi_data, popdi_cols, cradi_cols, udi_cols)  # View results head(scored_pfdi)

title: Getting Started with urogynScorer
text: Patient Global Impression Improvement (PGI-) scale measures subjective improvement following treatment:
code: # Create sample PGI-I data pgii_data <- data.frame(   Record_ID = c("PT001", "PT002", "PT003", "PT004", "PT005"),   pgii_response = c(1, 2, 3, 4, NA)  # 1=Very much better, 7=Very much worse )  # Score PGI-I responses pgii_results <- score_pgii(   patient_data = pgii_data,   item_name = "pgii_response",   keep_n_valid = TRUE,   verbose = FALSE )  # View results pgii_results #> # A tibble: 5 × 4 #>   Record_ID pgii_score pgii_improved pgii_n_valid #>   <chr>          <dbl>         <dbl>        <int> #> 1 PT001              1             1            4 #> 2 PT002              2             1            4 #> 3 PT003              3             1            4 #> 4 PT004              4             0            4 #> 5 PT005             NA            NA            4

title: Getting Started with urogynScorer
text: Sandvik Severity Index measures urinary incontinence severity:
code: # Create sample frequency and amount data frequency <- c(0, 1, 2, 3, 4)  # 0=Never to 4=Daily amount <- c(1, 2, 3, 2, 1)     # 1=Drops to 3=Large amounts  # Calculate Sandvik Severity Index sandvik_results <- sandvik_severity_index(frequency, amount)  # View results sandvik_results #> # A tibble: 5 × 4 #>   Frequency Amount Severity_Index Severity_Level #>       <dbl>  <dbl>          <dbl> <chr>          #> 1         0      1              0 Slight         #> 2         1      2              2 Moderate       #> 3         2      3              6 Severe         #> 4         3      2              6 Severe         #> 5         4      1              4 Moderate

title: Getting Started with urogynScorer
text: calculate_pfdi_scores() function supports several column naming conventions, including: Standard format: popdi_q*, cradi_q*, udi_q* Numeric format: PFDI-1 PFDI-20 Subscale-specific format: PFDI-POPDI-*, PFDI-CRADI-*, PFDI-UDI-* Dot notation: PFDI.1, PFDI.2, etc.

title: Getting Started with urogynScorer
text: PGI-responses must integers 1 7, : - 1: much better - 2: Much better - 3: little better - 4: change - 5: little worse - 6: Much worse - 7: much worse score_pgii() function adds binary improvement indicator (1 = improved [1-3], 0 = improved [4-7]).

title: Calculate Scores for Urogynecology Questionnaires
text: Tyler Muffly, MD 2025-03-28

title: Calculate Scores for Urogynecology Questionnaires
text: urogynScorer provides functions scoring validated patient-reported outcome measures used urogynecology clinical practice research. package implements evidence-based scoring algorithms comprehensive validation error handling : Pelvic Organ Prolapse Distress Inventory (POPDI-6) Colorectal-Anal Distress Inventory (CRADI-8) Urinary Distress Inventory (UDI-6) Pelvic Floor Impact Questionnaire (PFIQ-7) Pelvic Organ Prolapse/Urinary Incontinence Sexual Questionnaire (PISQ-12) Overactive Bladder Questionnaire Short Form (OAB-q SF) International Consultation Incontinence Questionnaire-Urinary Incontinence Short Form (ICIQ-UI SF) Patient Global Impression Improvement (PGI-) Sandvik Severity Index urinary incontinence

title: Calculate Scores for Urogynecology Questionnaires
code: install.packages("urogynScorer")

title: Calculate Scores for Urogynecology Questionnaires
code: # Install devtools if you haven't already install.packages("devtools")  # Install the development version from GitHub devtools::install_github("mufflyt/urogynScorer")

title: Calculate Scores for Urogynecology Questionnaires
text: Automated, standardized scoring following validated methodologies Robust handling missing data following instrument-specific guidelines Comprehensive input validation informative error messages Detailed logging capabilities quality assurance debugging Elegant handling alternative column naming conventions Tidy output compatible tidyverse ecosystem Extensive documentation examples references primary literature

title: Calculate Scores for Urogynecology Questionnaires
text: Pelvic Floor Distress Inventory (PFDI-20) measures pelvic floor symptoms across three domains:
code: library(urogynScorer) library(dplyr)  # Load sample data data("pfdi_data_minimal")  # View first few rows head(pfdi_data_minimal)  # Score PFDI-20 pfdi_results <- calculate_pfdi_scores(   patient_data = pfdi_data_minimal,   id_column = "Record_ID",   missing_threshold = 0.5,  # Allow up to 50% missing data per subscale   verbose = TRUE            # Enable detailed logging )  # View results pfdi_results

what: Pelvic Organ Prolapse/Urinary Incontinence Sexual Questionnaire (PISQ-12)
title: Calculate Scores for Urogynecology Questionnaires
text: Pelvic Organ Prolapse/Urinary Incontinence Sexual Questionnaire (PISQ-12) condition-specific tool evaluates sexual function women pelvic organ prolapse /urinary incontinence:
code: # Create sample data pisq_data <- data.frame(   Record_ID = c("PT001", "PT002", "PT003"),   pisq_q1 = c(2, 3, 1),    # Questions 1-4 are scored 0-4 (higher = better)   pisq_q2 = c(3, 2, 0),   pisq_q3 = c(1, 2, 4),   pisq_q4 = c(2, 1, 3),   pisq_q5 = c(2, 1, 0),    # Questions 5-12 are scored 0-4 (lower = better)   pisq_q6 = c(1, 2, 3),   pisq_q7 = c(0, 1, 2),   pisq_q8 = c(1, 0, 2),   pisq_q9 = c(2, 1, 0),   pisq_q10 = c(3, 2, 1),   pisq_q11 = c(1, 2, 0),   pisq_q12 = c(0, 1, 3) )  # Score PISQ-12 pisq_results <- calculate_pisq12(   questionnaire_data = pisq_data,   id_column = "Record_ID",   missing_threshold = 0.2,  # Allow up to 20% missing data   verbose = TRUE            # Enable detailed logging )  # View results pisq_results

what: International Consultation on Incontinence Questionnaire-Urinary Incontinence Short Form (ICIQ-UI SF)
title: Calculate Scores for Urogynecology Questionnaires
text: ICIQ-UI SF measures urinary incontinence symptoms impact quality life:
code: # Create sample data iciq_data <- data.frame(   patient_id = c("P001", "P002", "P003"),   iciq_1 = c(2, 3, 1),     # Frequency (0-5)   iciq_2 = c(4, 2, 0),     # Volume (0-6)   iciq_3 = c(6, 8, 3),     # Impact (0-10)   iciq_4_1 = c(1, 0, 0),   # Situation: leaks before reaching toilet   iciq_4_2 = c(0, 1, 0),   # Situation: leaks when coughing/sneezing   iciq_4_3 = c(0, 0, 1),   # Situation: leaks when asleep   iciq_4_4 = c(0, 1, 0),   # Situation: leaks with physical activity   iciq_4_5 = c(1, 0, 0),   # Situation: leaks when finished urinating   iciq_4_6 = c(0, 0, 0),   # Situation: leaks for no obvious reason   iciq_4_7 = c(0, 0, 0)    # Situation: leaks all the time )  # Score ICIQ-UI SF iciq_results <- calculate_iciq_ui_sf(   questionnaire_data = iciq_data,   id_column = "patient_id",   missing_threshold = 0.0,  # No missing values allowed by default   verbose = TRUE            # Enable detailed logging )  # View results iciq_results

what: Overactive Bladder Questionnaire Short Form (OAB-q SF)
title: Calculate Scores for Urogynecology Questionnaires
text: OAB-q SF evaluates symptom bother health-related quality life patients overactive bladder:
code: # Create sample data oab_data <- data.frame(   patient_id = c("P001", "P002", "P003"),   oab_1 = c(2, 4, 3),      # Symptom items (1-6)   oab_2 = c(3, 5, 2),   oab_3 = c(4, 3, 1),   oab_4 = c(2, 4, 3),   oab_5 = c(3, 2, 4),   oab_6 = c(1, 3, 2),   oab_7 = c(4, 2, 5),      # HRQL items (7-19)   oab_8 = c(5, 3, 4),   oab_9 = c(3, 4, 5),   oab_10 = c(4, 3, 4),   oab_11 = c(5, 2, 3),   oab_12 = c(4, 3, 5),   oab_13 = c(3, 4, 4),   oab_14 = c(5, 3, 3),   oab_15 = c(4, 5, 4),   oab_16 = c(3, 4, 5),   oab_17 = c(4, 3, 4),   oab_18 = c(5, 4, 3),   oab_19 = c(4, 5, 4) )  # Score OAB-q SF oab_results <- calculate_oabq_sf(   questionnaire_data = oab_data,   id_column = "patient_id",   symptom_missing_threshold = 0.5,  # Allow up to 50% missing data for symptom scale   hrql_missing_threshold = 0.5,     # Allow up to 50% missing data for HRQL scale   verbose = TRUE                    # Enable detailed logging )  # View results oab_results

title: Calculate Scores for Urogynecology Questionnaires
text: PGI-assesses patient-reported improvement following treatment 7-point scale:
code: # Create sample data pgii_data <- data.frame(   Record_ID = c("PT001", "PT002", "PT003", "PT004", "PT005"),   pgii_response = c(1, 2, 3, 4, NA)  # 1=Very much better, 7=Very much worse )  # Score PGI-I responses pgii_results <- score_pgii(   patient_data = pgii_data,   item_name = "pgii_response",   keep_n_valid = TRUE,   verbose = TRUE )  # View results pgii_results

title: Calculate Scores for Urogynecology Questionnaires
text: Sandvik index categorizes urinary incontinence severity based frequency amount leakage:
code: # Create sample data sandvik_data <- tibble::tibble(   frequency = c(1, 2, 3, 4, 0),  # 0=Never to 4=Daily   amount = c(1, 2, 3, 2, 1)      # 1=Drops to 3=Large amounts )  # Calculate Sandvik Severity Index sandvik_results <- sandvik_severity_index(   frequency = sandvik_data$frequency,   amount = sandvik_data$amount )  # View results sandvik_results

what: Pelvic Organ Prolapse/Urinary Incontinence Sexual Questionnaire (PISQ-12) Items
title: Calculate Scores for Urogynecology Questionnaires
text: PISQ-12 assesses sexual function women pelvic floor disorders: frequently feel sexual desire? feeling may include wanting sex, planning sex, feeling frustrated due lack sex, etc. climax (orgasm) sexual intercourse partner? feel sexually excited (turned ) sexual activity partner? satisfied variety sexual activities current sex life? feel pain sexual intercourse? incontinent urine (leak urine) sexual activity? fear incontinence (either stool urine) restrict sexual activity? avoid sexual intercourse bulging vagina (either bladder, rectum, vagina falling )? sex partner, negative emotional reactions fear, disgust, shame guilt? partner problem erections affects sexual activity? partner problem premature ejaculation affects sexual activity? Compared orgasms past, intense orgasms past six months? item scored scale 0-4: - 0: Always - 1: Usually - 2: Sometimes - 3: Seldom - 4: Never questions 1-4, scoring reversed (0=4, 1=3, etc.) since positively phrased.

title: Calculate Scores for Urogynecology Questionnaires
text: PFDI-20 consists three subscales: question uses 0-4 scale: Scoring process: 1. Calculate mean score subscale (≥50% items answered) 2. Multiply mean 25 get 0-100 scale 3. Sum three subscale scores get PFDI-20 total (0-300 scale)

title: Calculate Scores for Urogynecology Questionnaires
text: ICIQ-UI SF consists 4 items: Scoring process: 1. Sum items 1-3 get total score (range 0-21) 2. Higher scores indicate greater severity: - 1-5: Mild urinary incontinence - 6-12: Moderate urinary incontinence - 13-21: Severe urinary incontinence 3. Item 4 (situations) provides diagnostic information type incontinence

title: Calculate Scores for Urogynecology Questionnaires
text: PFIQ-7 consists three scales 7 questions : question scored 0-3: - 0: - 1: Somewhat - 2: Moderately - 3: Quite bit Scoring process: 1. Calculate sum scale 2. Multiply (100/21) get 0-100 scale 3. Sum three scales get total PFIQ-7 score (0-300 scale)

title: Calculate Scores for Urogynecology Questionnaires
text: Pelvic Organ Prolapse/Urinary Incontinence Sexual Questionnaire (PISQ-12) evaluates sexual function women pelvic floor disorders: question scored 0-4: - 0: Always - 1: Usually - 2: Sometimes - 3: Seldom - 4: Never Scoring process: 1. Reverse-code questions 1-4 (0=4, 1=3, etc.) 2. Sum items (range 0-48) 3. Transform 0-100 scale: (score/48) × 100 4. Higher scores indicate better sexual function

title: Calculate Scores for Urogynecology Questionnaires
text: OAB-q SF consists two scales: question scored 1-6: - 1: - 2: little bit - 3: Somewhat - 4: Quite bit - 5: great deal - 6: great deal Scoring process: 1. Calculate raw scores scale (sum items) 2. Transform 0-100 scale using formula: ((mean-1)/5) × 100 3. Symptom Bother scale, higher scores indicate greater symptom bother 4. HRQL scale, higher scores indicate better quality life

title: Calculate ICIQ-UI SF (International Consultation on Incontinence Questionnaire-Urinary Incontinence Short Form) Scores — calculate_iciq_ui_sf
text: questionnaire_data data frame containing ICIQ-UI SF item responses. Column names follow pattern specified parameters default structure. id_column Character string specifying column name containing patient identifiers. NULL (default), ID column used. frequency_item Character string specifying column name containing frequency question (item 1). Default "iciq_1". volume_item Character string specifying column name containing leakage amount question (item 2). Default "iciq_2". impact_item Character string specifying column name containing quality life impact question (item 3). Default "iciq_3". situation_prefix Character string specifying prefix situation columns (item 4). Default "iciq_4_". calculate_situations Logical indicating whether analyze incontinence situations. Default TRUE. missing_threshold Numeric value 0 1 specifying maximum proportion missing values allowed core items (1-3). Default 0.0 (missing values allowed). verbose Logical indicating whether display detailed logging information. Default FALSE.

title: Calculate ICIQ-UI SF (International Consultation on Incontinence Questionnaire-Urinary Incontinence Short Form) Scores — calculate_iciq_ui_sf
text: data frame containing original data plus additional columns: iciq_score: ICIQ-UI SF total score (sum items 1-3), ranging 0-21, higher scores indicating greater severity. frequency_score: Score urinary frequency (item 1, 0-5). volume_score: Score leakage amount (item 2, 0-6). impact_score: Score quality life impact (item 3, 0-10). iciq_missing: Count missing core items (1-3). iciq_valid: Logical indicating score valid. situation_*: calculate_situations=TRUE, columns incontinence situation.

title: Calculate ICIQ-UI SF (International Consultation on Incontinence Questionnaire-Urinary Incontinence Short Form) Scores — calculate_iciq_ui_sf
text: ICIQ-UI SF consists 4 items: Item 1: Frequency urinary leakage (scored 0-5) Item 2: Amount leakage (scored 0-6) Item 3: Impact quality life (scored 0-10) Item 4: Situations leakage occurs (scored, diagnostic ) total ICIQ-UI SF score sum items 1-3, ranging 0-21: 1-5: Mild urinary incontinence 6-12: Moderate urinary incontinence 13-21: Severe urinary incontinence Missing data handling: default, items 1-3 missing, score set NA can customized missing_threshold parameter Missing situation items (item 4) treated "selected"

what: Calculate OAB-q SF (Overactive Bladder Questionnaire Short Form) Scores — calculate_oabq_sf
title: Calculate OAB-q SF (Overactive Bladder Questionnaire Short Form) Scores — calculate_oabq_sf
text: Calculates scores Overactive Bladder Questionnaire Short Form (OAB-q SF), validated instrument measuring symptom bother health-related quality life patients overactive bladder. function includes robust validation, handles missing data according scoring guidelines, includes detailed logging.

title: Calculate OAB-q SF (Overactive Bladder Questionnaire Short Form) Scores — calculate_oabq_sf
code: calculate_oabq_sf(   questionnaire_data,   id_column = NULL,   item_prefix = "oab_",   symptom_items = 1:6,   hrql_items = 7:19,   symptom_missing_threshold = 0.5,   hrql_missing_threshold = 0.5,   verbose = FALSE )

title: Calculate OAB-q SF (Overactive Bladder Questionnaire Short Form) Scores — calculate_oabq_sf
text: questionnaire_data data frame containing OAB-q SF item responses. Column names follow pattern specified item_prefix parameter followed item number (e.g., "oab_1", "oab_2", etc.). id_column Character string specifying column name containing patient identifiers. NULL (default), ID column used. item_prefix character string specifying prefix OAB-q SF column names. Default "oab_". symptom_items numeric vector specifying items belong symptom bother scale. Default items 1-6. hrql_items numeric vector specifying items belong health-related quality life scale. Default items 7-19. symptom_missing_threshold Numeric value 0 1 specifying maximum proportion missing values allowed symptom scale. Default 0.5 (50%). hrql_missing_threshold Numeric value 0 1 specifying maximum proportion missing values allowed HRQL scale. Default 0.5 (50%). verbose Logical indicating whether display detailed logging information. Default FALSE.

title: Calculate OAB-q SF (Overactive Bladder Questionnaire Short Form) Scores — calculate_oabq_sf
text: data frame containing original data plus additional columns: symptom_score: OAB-q SF Symptom Bother scale score, transformed 0-100 scale higher scores indicate greater symptom bother. hrql_score: OAB-q SF Health-Related Quality Life scale score, transformed 0-100 scale higher scores indicate better quality life. symptom_missing: Count missing items Symptom Bother scale. hrql_missing: Count missing items HRQL scale. symptom_valid: Logical indicating Symptom Bother score valid (TRUE missing proportion <= symptom_missing_threshold). hrql_valid: Logical indicating HRQL score valid (TRUE missing proportion <= hrql_missing_threshold). total_valid: Logical indicating scores valid.

title: Calculate OAB-q SF (Overactive Bladder Questionnaire Short Form) Scores — calculate_oabq_sf
text: OAB-q SF consists 19 items across two scales: Symptom Bother (6 items): Measures degree bother associated overactive bladder symptoms. Health-Related Quality Life (13 items): Measures impact overactive bladder various aspects quality life. item scored 1-6, higher scores indicating greater bother Symptom scale better quality life HRQL scale. Missing data handled according established guidelines: 50% items (custom threshold) missing scale, scale's score set NA. fewer items missing, mean completed items used impute missing values. Scores transformed 0-100 scale using formula: $$Transformed Score = \frac{(Raw Score - Min) \times 100}{(Max - Min)}$$

what: Calculate PFDI Scores from Minimal Dataset — calculate_pfdi_scores
title: Calculate PFDI Scores from Minimal Dataset — calculate_pfdi_scores
text: Calculates Pelvic Floor Distress Inventory (PFDI-20) total score subscale scores (POPDI-6, CRADI-8, UDI-6) raw questionnaire data.

title: Calculate PFDI Scores from Minimal Dataset — calculate_pfdi_scores
code: calculate_pfdi_scores(   input_data = NULL,   id_column = "Record_ID",   missing_threshold = 0.5,   verbose = FALSE,   output_file = NULL,   scale_factor = 25,   patient_data = NULL )

title: Calculate PFDI Scores from Minimal Dataset — calculate_pfdi_scores
text: input_data data frame containing PFDI questionnaire responses. id_column Character string specifying column name containing patient identifiers. Default "Record_ID". missing_threshold Numeric value 0 1 specifying maximum proportion missing values allowed per subscale. Default 0.5 (50%). verbose Logical indicating whether print detailed logging messages. Default FALSE. output_file Character string specifying path save results. NULL (default), results saved file. scale_factor Numeric. scaling factor apply scores. Default 25. patient_data Deprecated. Use input_data instead. data frame containing PFDI questionnaire responses.

title: Calculate PFDI Scores from Minimal Dataset — calculate_pfdi_scores
text: tibble containing patient IDs calculated scores PFDI-20 total three subscales (POPDI-6, CRADI-8, UDI-6).

title: Calculate PFDI Scores from Minimal Dataset — calculate_pfdi_scores
text: PFDI-20 consists three subscales: POPDI-6 (questions 1-6), CRADI-8 (questions 7-14), UDI-6 (questions 15-20). question uses 0-4 scale. function calculates mean score subscale, multiplies scale factor (default: 25) get 0-100 scale, sums three subscale scores get PFDI-20 total (0-300 scale). function supports multiple column naming conventions including standard format (popdi_q*, cradi_q*, udi_q*), numeric format (PFDI-1 PFDI-20), subscale-specific format (PFDI-POPDI-*, etc.), dot notation (PFDI.1, etc.).

title: Calculate PFDI Scores from Minimal Dataset — calculate_pfdi_scores

= 3, udi_q2 = 1, udi_q3 = 0 ) pfdi_scores <- calculate_pfdi_scores(   input_data = patient_data,   scale_factor = 25,   verbose = TRUE ) #> INFO [2025-03-29 03:51:44] Starting PFDI score calculation what: Calculate PFIQ-7 (Pelvic Floor Impact Questionnaire) Scores — calculate_pfiq7
title: Calculate PFIQ-7 (Pelvic Floor Impact Questionnaire) Scores — calculate_pfiq7
text: Calculates domain-specific total scores PFIQ-7 questionnaire, measures impact pelvic floor disorders quality life across three domains: urinary (UIQ-7), colorectal-anal (CRAIQ-7), pelvic organ prolapse (POPIQ-7).

title: Calculate PFIQ-7 (Pelvic Floor Impact Questionnaire) Scores — calculate_pfiq7
code: calculate_pfiq7(questionnaire_data, verbose = FALSE)

title: Calculate PFIQ-7 (Pelvic Floor Impact Questionnaire) Scores — calculate_pfiq7
text: questionnaire_data data frame containing PFIQ-7 responses 21 columns (7 questions × 3 domains). Column names follow pattern 'uiq1', 'uiq2', ..., 'craiq1', 'craiq2', ..., 'popiq1', 'popiq2', etc. verbose Logical indicating whether print detailed logging information calculation. Default FALSE.

title: Calculate PFIQ-7 (Pelvic Floor Impact Questionnaire) Scores — calculate_pfiq7
text: data frame calculated scores domain (UIQ-7, CRAIQ-7, POPIQ-7) total PFIQ-7 score. score ranges 0 100, higher scores indicating greater impact quality life.

title: Calculate PFIQ-7 (Pelvic Floor Impact Questionnaire) Scores — calculate_pfiq7
text: PFIQ-7 consists three scales 7 questions : UIQ-7: Questions urinary symptoms CRAIQ-7: Questions colorectal-anal symptoms POPIQ-7: Questions pelvic organ prolapse symptoms question scored 0 3: 0: 1: Somewhat 2: Moderately 3: Quite bit Domain scores calculated : (sum domain item scores) * (100/21) Total PFIQ-7 score sum three domain scores (range 0-300)

what: Calculate PISQ-12 (Pelvic Organ Prolapse/Urinary Incontinence Sexual Questionnaire) Scores — calculate_pisq12
title: Calculate PISQ-12 (Pelvic Organ Prolapse/Urinary Incontinence Sexual Questionnaire) Scores — calculate_pisq12
text: Calculates Pelvic Organ Prolapse/Urinary Incontinence Sexual Questionnaire (PISQ-12) score, measures sexual function women pelvic floor disorders. function handles missing data, performs reverse scoring appropriate items, validates inputs according scoring guidelines.

title: Calculate PISQ-12 (Pelvic Organ Prolapse/Urinary Incontinence Sexual Questionnaire) Scores — calculate_pisq12
code: calculate_pisq12(   questionnaire_data,   id_column = NULL,   item_prefix = "pisq_",   reverse_items = c(1, 2, 3, 4),   max_missing = 2,   scale_to_100 = FALSE,   verbose = FALSE )

title: Calculate PISQ-12 (Pelvic Organ Prolapse/Urinary Incontinence Sexual Questionnaire) Scores — calculate_pisq12
text: questionnaire_data data frame containing PISQ-12 item responses. Column names follow pattern specified item_prefix parameter followed item number (e.g., "pisq_1", "pisq_2", etc.). id_column Character string specifying column name containing patient identifiers. NULL (default), ID column used. item_prefix character string specifying prefix PISQ-12 column names. Default "pisq_". reverse_items numeric vector specifying items reverse-scored. Default items 1, 2, 3, 4, positively phrased items. max_missing maximum number missing items allowed score set NA. Default 2 (2 missing items permitted). scale_to_100 Logical indicating whether scale scores 0-100 range. Default FALSE (returns raw scores 0-48). verbose Logical indicating whether display detailed logging information. Default FALSE.

title: Calculate PISQ-12 (Pelvic Organ Prolapse/Urinary Incontinence Sexual Questionnaire) Scores — calculate_pisq12
text: data frame containing original data plus additional columns: pisq12_score: PISQ-12 score. scale_to_100 = TRUE, scores range 0-100, higher scores indicating better sexual function. Otherwise, scores range 0-48. pisq12_missing: Count missing items respondent. pisq12_valid: Logical indicating score valid (TRUE missing items <= max_missing).

title: Calculate PISQ-12 (Pelvic Organ Prolapse/Urinary Incontinence Sexual Questionnaire) Scores — calculate_pisq12
text: PISQ-12 consists 12 items measuring sexual function across three domains: behavioral/emotive (items 1-4), physical (items 5-9), partner-related (items 10-12). item scored 0 (always) 4 (never). Items 1-4 ask positive aspects sexual function reverse-scored higher scores indicate better function. items, necessary reverse-scoring, higher scores indicate better sexual function. Missing data handled : Calculating mean answered items Substituting mean missing values Multiplying 12/(12-n), n number missing items max_missing items missing, score set NA

title: Sandvik Severity Index Calculation — sandvik_severity_index
text: frequency Numeric vector values 0 4 representing frequency incontinence episodes. 0: Never 1: Less month 2: times month 3: times week 4: Every day /night amount Numeric vector values 1 3 representing amount leakage. 1: Drops 2: Small amounts 3: Large amounts

title: Sandvik Severity Index Calculation — sandvik_severity_index
text: tibble following columns: Frequency - input frequency incontinence. Amount - input amount leakage. Severity_Index - computed Sandvik Severity Index (Frequency * Amount). Severity_Level - categorized severity level: "Slight" (≤ 1) "Moderate" (2-5) "Severe" (6-9) "Severe" (≥ 10)

title: Sandvik Severity Index Calculation — sandvik_severity_index

what: Score the Patient Global Impression of Improvement (PGI-I) — score_pgii
title: Score the Patient Global Impression of Improvement (PGI-I) — score_pgii
text: Scores PGI-, single-item measure assessing patient-reported improvement following treatment. function includes robust input validation, detailed logging, handles missing values according scoring guidelines.

title: Score the Patient Global Impression of Improvement (PGI-I) — score_pgii
code: score_pgii(   patient_data,   item_name,   id_column = "Record_ID",   keep_n_valid = FALSE,   verbose = FALSE,   output_file = NULL )

title: Score the Patient Global Impression of Improvement (PGI-I) — score_pgii
text: patient_data data frame containing PGI-response variable. item_name column name data frame contains PGI-response. must valid column patient_data containing values 1-7 NA. id_column Character string specifying column name containing patient identifiers. Default "Record_ID". keep_n_valid Logical, whether return number valid, non-missing responses output. Default FALSE. verbose Logical indicating whether print detailed logging messages. Default FALSE. output_file Character string specifying path save results. NULL (default), results saved file.

title: Score the Patient Global Impression of Improvement (PGI-I) — score_pgii
text: data frame containing: pgii_score - original PGI-response score (1-7 NA) pgii_improved - binary variable indicating patient reported improvement (scores 1 3 considered improvement, scores 4 7 considered improvement/worsening) pgii_n_valid - (Optional) number valid responses

title: Score the Patient Global Impression of Improvement (PGI-I) — score_pgii
text: PGI-single-item global rating scale patients rate improvement treatment scale 1 (much better) 7 (much worse). Lower scores indicate better perceived improvement. PGI-response scale: 1: much better 2: Much better 3: little better 4: change 5: little worse 6: Much worse 7: much worse

title: Score the Patient Global Impression of Improvement (PGI-I) — score_pgii
text: PGI-response missing (NA), function return NA score binary improvement indicator.

title: Score the Patient Global Impression of Improvement (PGI-I) — score_pgii
text: Yalcin, ., & Bump, R. C. (2003). Validation two global impression questionnaires incontinence. American Journal Obstetrics Gynecology, 189(1), 98-101.

what: urogynScorer: Calculate Scores for Urogynecology Questionnaires — urogynScorer-package
title: urogynScorer: Calculate Scores for Urogynecology Questionnaires — urogynScorer-package
text: comprehensive toolkit scoring, validating, analyzing patient-reported outcome measures (PROMs) used urogynecology pelvic floor medicine. package implements standardized scoring algorithms robust validation commonly used questionnaires including PFDI-20, PGI-, Sandvik Severity Index. comprehensive toolkit scoring, validating, analyzing patient-reported outcome measures (PROMs) used urogynecology pelvic floor medicine. package implements standardized scoring algorithms robust validation commonly used questionnaires clinical practice research.

title: urogynScorer: Calculate Scores for Urogynecology Questionnaires — urogynScorer-package
text: package provides functions scoring: Pelvic Floor Distress Inventory (PFDI-20) - Including subscales: Pelvic Organ Prolapse Distress Inventory (POPDI-6) Colorectal-Anal Distress Inventory (CRADI-8) Urinary Distress Inventory (UDI-6) Patient Global Impression Improvement (PGI-) - single-item measure subjective treatment efficacy Sandvik Severity Index - assessing urinary incontinence severity Key features include: Evidence-based handling missing data Robust validation input data Detailed logging capabilities Comprehensive documentation clinical context Support multiple column naming conventions

Sandvik H, Seim , Vanvik , Hunskaar S (2000). severity index epidemiological surveys female urinary incontinence: Comparison 48-hour pad-weighing tests. Neurourology Urodynamics, 19(2), 137-145.
